displayed_text: Family Member: Good to see you. Other than that, Doctor: Yeah. I think she’s got a questionnaire or two for you. Okay. I’ll let A_ know. Patient: Now, you’re gonna, now they’re gonna check the pharmacy and let me know? Doctor: Yes. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I have to – I give it to our pharmacist, and then she’ll start processing it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But it’ll take a day or two. Family Member: Alright. Thank you again.

Patient: So I have to call them and let them know I’m not coming in there tomorrow. Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. So otherwise you feeling okay? Nothing changed? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And you’re taking your Casodex? Patient: Yes. Healthcare Professional: Mhmm. Doctor: Okay. Alright so I think we’re gonna have to contact you back (pause) Patient: Okay. Doctor: …correctly for you then we have to switch to a different medicine. Okay. So go ahead and stop the Casodex. Okay? Patient: The - The Casodex I don’t – don’t take the Casodex?

Patient: Yeah. I got to say this only happened probably all that driving. Doctor: Yeah. If that’s no better, we need to know. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Oh hi, Come on in. Healthcare Professional: Hello. Patient: How are you doing? Doctor: We chatted about all sorts of things. Healthcare Professional: What did you give him because I have him coming back for the spinal? Doctor: He’ll come back after he gets scanned which will probably be like in a week or two. Healthcare Professional: Okay, so then we will, because he’s due to come back on the 18th and he’ll have research labs then, so that will be a different one. Doctor: I think so. We’ll try to make sure that we have a plan. Healthcare Professional: Okay Doctor: He can’t get rid of us now. Sit tight.

Patient: Pat We’re looking at potent—very, uh, plausibly potential choices down the road. Doctor: Yes. Patient: And, and, and so at this point --- Doctor: I mean, including standard of care. So, standard of care is always our baseline. Patient: Right. Doctor: And then we, you know, I could just, my description will be, “here’s what standard of care does, here’s what we expect.” Patient: Well, well, I guess what I’m asking, if my PSA stays down - Doctor: The standard of care is – Patient: We should do nothing. Doctor: Is continue just doing what we’re doing. Patient: Eve—even, not even the clinical trial? Doctor: Right. One of the reasons for that has to do with, you know, how do we evaluate you on a clinical trial? What are our markers? PSA level?

Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: Um and uh this will allow me use with along with our other researchers for future use. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: Um so you can see it was important for me to talk to the radiologist to make sure that we can do it safely and that we can get enough samples to make it worth everybody’s while. Okay. Questions. Patient: Um n- well observations. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: They – it it did say for example… Doctor: Mhmm. Patient: …gall bladder, fossa, largest not quite two centimeters… Doctor: Right. Patient: …which is not quite an inch. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: I do understand the sample thing because…

Family Member: Yes. He’s gotten it. Doctor: Did you get a flu shot this year? Patient: Yep. Doctor: You got it in September, October, November? Family Member: September. Yes. Patient: September. Doctor: Okay. I’m going to just let her know the camera may have done something. Healthcare Professional: The paper towel looks like. Doctor: You said it’s okay? Okay. How are you? Patient: Hum, all right, except my neck hurts where that rod is. Doctor: Okay. And, huh, so you scored your pain a six. Was that for that pain or to the abdomen? Patient: Oh, that’s when, huh, they gave me the needle. I told her. Doctor: Okay. Good. But six isn’t your neck or-?

Family Member: Hormone therapy does? Doctor: Yeah, because it castrates you. It puts you into menopause. And we can talk some more about that. The um uh - another approach, so if we do that; let’s just focus on that, knowing that the cancer is down here in the pelvis, if you look at all the guys that get treated with radiation plus hormones and you look five years from now- Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: everybody’s alive, okay. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: Half the guys have their cancer come back, meaning they weren’t cured by the surgery, radiation and hormones. Half of the guys are cured by the hormones and radiation. You know it sort of mops up what’s left. Okay, so at minimum the standard of care is for you to do radiation plus hormones. I can tell you why they have the hormones. If they do the radiation alone, only thirty percent of the guys are cured five years from now. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: The good news is just so you hear it, is half the guys are cured at five years and then if you look ten years down – Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: - the line, nine out of ten guys are still alive if you go through the hormones and surgery, hormones and radiation, okay. Patient: Sure, uh hum. Doctor: You may be fighting prostate cancer, but you’re alive.

Patient: Well, last time I got the bone scan in D___. Doctor: I know. Yes. Yes. Patient: B___ C___. Doctor: Yeah. Whatever. So in between, I may, I may just give you a script to hold on for a PSA. Okay? Patient: Yes. Yes. Doctor: Like six weeks or so. If the PSA creeps up a little bit, I may want that in-between lab work. Okay? But, otherwise, I, if everything looks good, and- Patient: Very good. Okay. Sounds good. Doctor: Okay? Family Member: So what would the, uh, CAT scan show today? Just soft tissue? Patient: She doesn’t know yet. Family Member: maybe it’ll show Doctor: Well, I think maybe his disease was mainly in the lymph nodes. So that is what we will be following and the spine is visible on the CAT scan, too. Family Member: Okay.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the last 2 years (1 year but less: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the last 2 years (1 year but less than 2 years ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.1 time: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::1 time

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Black or African American: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Black or African American

displayed_text: Patient: Back home laughs]] Doctor: Yeah, they are. Patient: laughs]] Okay. Doctor: This is your script for the PSA level and I need to give you um the scan order and everything so we’ll this same thing in three months when you come back. Patient: Okay, okay. Doctor: Okay? And let me look into your XGEVA injection. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You just can’t overdo it or you’re gonna be in the hospital between here and F___. You just got to be careful. Even if you end up in the hospital you just call me and I’ll work with your docs. It will be fine. Okay. So just get rest on the road. Patient: Oh yeah, oh yeah. Doctor: Okay. Alright. Patient: I mean you know I ain’t stupid. Doctor: Hi. Healthcare Professional: Hi. Patient: Get it done. Come on C__, come on over here. Doctor: She’s out of here. Patient: You know what man. Doctor: Here’s your starter kit. Patient: What is this?. Doctor: There’s some information for you about what this medicine is. And this medicine so see… no wait (pages turning)

Family Member: I had a question about if it does cause nausea (pause) Doctor: Yes. Family Member: Does that last the full three weeks or does it taper off? Doctor: Oh no. Most – I would not expect you to have significant nausea at all. I am going to give you a prescription on you know Zofran in case you need it. But most people don’t need more than what we give them today, right. Okay, so it’s not expected. Once in a while I guess if you have a major reaction, it’s okay to have it - Family Member: And so - Doctor: My hope is if this is a lot of this flare-up from the pain from the cancer, then actually we should start seeing an improvement ah without having to do - Patient: Well, that’s what I didn’t know was - Doctor: You know, and what raised my bar of suspicion is how much of this adrenal mass grew. Doctor: If the same kind of growth is happening in the bones, then you know it sort of took off all of a sudden, frankly. Family Member: Uh hum, right. Doctor: That made me think maybe the rest of your pain, also this big pain flare-up that you’re experiencing might be problematic Patient: Well see that’s - Doctor: But bone disease is always very hard to see.

Patient: If, if, if, if – Doctor: So, if the hormones alone are making those get better, better, better, we give you the trial, I have no way to know did it do anything. So, we usually wait until the hormone stops working by itself. Family Member: And, that’s all just gauged by a PSA or do you do the – Doctor: It’s gauged by PSA as a screening and then, you know, at some point we would then just re-image you, too. Family Member: Hmm. Doctor: But, our experience is, as long as the PSA’s going down, usually the imaging is either getting better or staying stable. So. Patient: If the PSA is that reliable in terms of – Doctor: Ehhh, it’s reliable enough. I don’t know, it’s not unbelievably reliable, but Patient: But, if – Doctor: Rather than, you know, trying to give you a CAT scan every month. Patient: It’s, it’s, it’s unlikely that the PSA is going to go up if things are okay. Doctor: Yes.

Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So that is why we give both drugs in combination. And what happens is on a monthly basis through about twenty-eight day treatment cycles the testosterone goes from being super-high, much higher than your body would be able to make on its own back down to super-low. PAT Uh huh. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So every twenty-eight days which is roughly every four weeks, your testosterone will spike for a few days and then within about a week it will drop down to the very low levels. Patient: When you say spike, what numbers have you seen? Doctor: Right, so I told you before that a real low testosterone level for someone your age might be let’s say a hundred fifty to two hundred milligrams per deciliter. Here, they’re talking about between one thousand and one thousand five hundred milligrams per deciliter. So it’s a five- to ten-fold increase above the physiological level. So we call this super-physiological. That means higher than physiological. Patient: Right, okay. Doctor: So again, since you’re not eligible for that at this point in time - Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: A minimum PSA for that trial has to be above one. Patient: Okay. Doctor: One point zero. But just to prepare for the future –

Patient: No. Doctor: You didn’t notice any different? Doctor: Okay so should we try going to five once a day or you don’t want to rock the boat? Patient: I suppose we could try it and see what happens. Doctor: We’re gonna try it. Family Member: Or even five one day and two the next and five one day and two the next. Doctor: I was just gonna say or maybe do it every other day. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: And see how you do. Patient: Yeah I can do that. Doctor: Because now if you’re not aggregating it with this medication… Patient: Oh yeah, yeah.
